column1: The Times' gentleman (a very difficult gent to please) is the loudest and noisiest of all
column2: and has made more hideous faces over the refreshment offered to him than any other critic. There is no use shirking this statement! when a man has been abused in the Times
column4: any more than he could hide the knowledge of his having been committed to prison by Mr. Henry
column5: or publicly caned in Pall Mall. You see it in your friends' eyes when they meet you. They know it. They have chuckled over it to a man. They whisper about it at the club
column6: and look over the paper at you. My next-door neighbor came to see me this morning
column7: and I saw by his face that he had the whole story pat. "Hem!" says he
column9: I HAVE heard of it; and the fact is
column10: they were talking about you at dinner last night
column11: and mentioning that the Times had—ahem!—'walked into you.'"
